In the perfect or _ imago _ state the May-fly lives a short time
The word _ ephemera _ means "
" living only for a day
though individuals may live longer
yet the term is fairly expressing their short existence
The May-flies ( _ Ephemeræ _ ) have all three long fine hairs at the end of the tail
some members of the same family but belonging to a different genus have only two hair-like appendages
known to fishermen as the " March-brown "
For instance the fly belongs to the same family as the May-fly
it is than it
it has only two hairs at the end of the tail
but with this exception the natural March-brown the May-fly are wonderfully
yet it is most to notice
what a wonderful difference there is in the larvæ of these two insects
Significant facts no doubt lie at the bottom of such differences in the case of insects so evidently allied

are
Come
we have lunched
we rested
we watched the May-flies
let
us try to catch a few more trout

why sometimes the fish will not rise
though the weather is the water in first-rate order
master Willy what game are you after now
he exclaimed
" Oh papa " " there are a lot of dace on this shallow "
so I put the spinning hooks on
see
I have managed to hook a couple out simply throwing the tackle on the other side of the fish then drawing it smartly through the water over them
Well that looks like a bit of poaching at all events just hook out some weed
the fish are spawning amongst that water-crowfoot no doubt
I dare say
we shall see some eggs
they are
there dotted over the long thread-like leaves of the plant , like little pearls
You have caught enough
for I think
it is not sportsmanlike to take such unfair advantage of the unfortunate dace
Put on your casting line
try under the old forge bridge
You think
there is not much use
A true fly-fisherman should never say so
I have taken many a trout under the bridge
I dare
say
you may be this time
I told you so
Keep your line tight
Jack shall land him
He is not a large fish very lively
Now you have him
throw him on the grass
Are there any parasites on him
we observed
Here is a leech-like rather small cylindrical
it is the _ Piscicola a not uncommon parasitic leech on fish
Well put him into the bottle
we can take him home
we examine him at leisure
How many trout have we taken now
" We have got nine papa "
remember
I have caught three
but I suppose
you include the poaching
I have caught three trout with the fly
I do n't count the dace
for I threw back again three small fish
is this showy plant with large , yellow , globe-like blossoms
How pretty it is growing in abundance in a little spot near the river
It is the globe
so called from the rounded shape of the corolla
it is of the buttercup family
as you will perhaps guess
In its wild state I believe so
it is found in mountain districts
I suspect
it has found its way here from some of the cottage gardens which are only a quarter of a mile distant

perhaps Mrs. Charlton would like them for her wild garden shrubbery

a-fishing always

they will be very
especially if the trout will not rise
you can leave at a cottager 's house
The trowel basket the bottles are to every angler-naturalist
What are you running after Jacko
Oh
I see one of the most beautiful insects that are found in this country
the most beautiful insects are found in this country
he is too for you
It is the brilliant steel-blue
Let
us sit down for a few minutes
us watch its flight
How rapidly it flies
now pursuing the course of the river now suddenly
darting back again
It is the _ Agrion virgo the most splendid of all the dragon-flies
even rivalling the gorgeously insects of tropical countries
coloured
All the dragon-flies proceed from water larvæ strange creatures of unbecoming forms and ferocious dispositions
The mouth rather the lower lip of the larva is of very singular form
Two jaw-like organs are at the end of the lip , its basal portion being articulated to the head
being articulated to the head
as it has been called
this mask is folded beneath the head when in repose
it can be suddenly shot out of the head so as to seize any small creatures
any small creatures may pass near it
which the larva thinks good to eat
Imagine one of your arms
being joined on to your chin
bend your elbow up
till your hand covers your face
this will represent the dragon larva with the mask in repose
now shoot out your arm in a straight line from the head
this will represent the mask unfolded in use
your fingers may be considered to represent the jaws of the creature
When the larva wishes to turn into an insect
it leaves the water
it creeps up the stem of some water weed or other object of the water
bursts its skin
it commences its new state of existence
If we look about us near the water side
we shall be to find some empty pupa skins
Here are on this sedge
you see a slit on the back through which the dragon-fly has come out
on the back through which the dragon-fly has come out
The dragon-flies are the most active of our British insects

The dragon-flies to quote the descriptive words of Professor Rymer Jones " are pre-eminently by the rapidity of their flight and the steadiness of their evolutions while hawking for prey in the vicinity of ponds and marshy grounds
where in hot summer weather they are everywhere to be met with
Equally conspicuous from their extreme activity , their gorgeous colours , and the exquisite structure of their wings they might be regarded as the monarchs of the insect race
selected for them entomologists

The very names would testify the perfection of their attributes their titles ranging from that of _ Anax imperator _ , indicative of imperial sway , to epithets expressive of feminine delicacy and ladylike grace , such as _ virgo _ , _ puella _ , _ demoiselle _ , and _ damsel-fly _ , which are appropriated to the sylph-like forms that many of them exhibit

that of _ Anax imperator _ indicative of imperial sway to epithets expressive of feminine delicacy and ladylike grace such as _ virgo _ , _ puella _ , _ demoiselle _ , and _ damsel-fly _ are appropriated to the sylph-like forms
that many of them exhibit
In their habits however they by no means deserve the gentle appellations
bestowed upon them
They are in truth the of the insect world
their whole lives are to bloodshed and rapine
possessed of acuteness of sight and rapidity of motion scarcely to be paralleled
Indomitable in their strength of wing furnished with tremendous jaws there seems "
terrible is the
they effect amongst the insect legions they are appointed to destroy
they are appointed to destroy
It must not however be supposed from the above description that the dragon-flies are creatures that deserve to be killed
that the dragon-flies are
deserve to be killed
On the contrary they are most to men
they destroy countless numbers of injurious flies and butterflies
whose larvæ do damage to vegetation

inherited the rural folks of our day from their great-great-grandmothers ' grandmothers

in America they are sometimes called _ devil darning-needles _
I believe
in Scotland they are known the name of _ flying adders _

now you have looked at him closely
